patterns.title: array_merge() inside loops (heuristic)
patterns.description: Detects array_merge() calls inside loops that can cause quadratic memory usage and performance degradation. The pattern $x = array_merge($x, ...) inside a loop creates a new array on each iteration.

patterns.title: Script/style versioning with time()
patterns.description: Using time() as the version parameter for wp_enqueue_script() or wp_enqueue_style() prevents browser caching and forces re-download on every page load, significantly impacting performance.

patterns.title: Disallowed PHP short tags
patterns.description: WordPress Coding Standards require full <?php tags instead of short tags (<?= or <? ). Short tags may not be enabled on all servers and can cause compatibility issues.

patterns.title: Duplicate capability strings across files
patterns.description: Detects current_user_can() and user_can() calls with hard-coded capability strings appearing in many files. While some duplication is normal (e.g., 'manage_options'), excessive duplication suggests capability checks should be centralized.

patterns.title: Duplicate function definitions across files
patterns.description: Detects exact function clones (Type 1) using hash-based comparison of normalized function bodies. Functions with identical logic (after removing comments and normalizing whitespace) appearing in multiple files indicate copy-paste violations.

patterns.title: Duplicate option names across files
patterns.description: Detects get_option(), update_option(), and delete_option() calls with hard-coded option names appearing in multiple files. This indicates a DRY violation where option names should be centralized as constants.

patterns.title: Duplicate transient keys across files
patterns.description: Detects get_transient(), set_transient(), and delete_transient() calls with hard-coded transient keys appearing in multiple files. This indicates a DRY violation where transient keys should be centralized as constants.

patterns.title: file_get_contents() with external URLs
patterns.description: Using file_get_contents() for external URLs is insecure and slow. WordPress provides wp_remote_get() which handles timeouts, SSL verification, and error handling properly.

patterns.title: get_users() without 'number' limit
patterns.description: Detects get_users() calls without the 'number' parameter, which can fetch ALL users from the database and cause memory exhaustion on large sites.

patterns.title: API keys/secrets exposed in client-side code
patterns.description: Detects API keys, secrets, tokens, or passwords that may be exposed in client-side JavaScript bundles. In headless WordPress setups, this commonly happens with NEXT_PUBLIC_ environment variables containing sensitive values.

patterns.title: fetch/axios calls without error handling
patterns.description: Detects fetch() or axios calls to WordPress REST API endpoints without proper error handling. Missing error handling leads to silent failures, broken UIs, and poor user experience.

patterns.title: GraphQL queries/mutations without error handling
patterns.description: Detects Apollo Client useQuery/useMutation hooks without error handling. Missing error handling in GraphQL operations leads to silent failures and broken UIs.

patterns.title: Hardcoded WordPress API URL
patterns.description: Detects hardcoded WordPress REST API or GraphQL URLs instead of environment variables. Hardcoded URLs break deployments across different environments (dev, staging, production).

patterns.title: WordPress REST API calls missing authentication
patterns.description: Detects fetch/axios calls to WordPress REST API endpoints that modify data (POST, PUT, DELETE) without proper authentication headers or credentials mode.

patterns.title: Next.js getStaticProps without revalidate (stale WordPress data)
patterns.description: Detects Next.js getStaticProps that fetch WordPress data but don't include a revalidate property, causing WordPress content to never update after initial build.

patterns.title: Duplicate localStorage/sessionStorage keys across files
patterns.description: Detects storage keys that appear in multiple JavaScript files. Duplicate storage keys indicate potential key collisions or inconsistent key management.

patterns.title: Query limit multiplier derived from count()
patterns.description: Detects patterns like count($ids) * N used to derive query limits/candidate limits. This can multiply unexpectedly and trigger OOM when combined with object hydration.

patterns.title: Potential command injection (child_process)
patterns.description: Detects usage of child_process.exec, execSync, or spawn with shell:true that may be vulnerable to command injection.

patterns.title: Dangerous eval() or code execution
patterns.description: Detects usage of eval(), Function constructor, and other code execution patterns that can lead to code injection vulnerabilities.

patterns.title: Potential path traversal in fs operations
patterns.description: Detects file system operations that may be vulnerable to path traversal attacks via '../' sequences in user input.

patterns.title: Promise without error handling
patterns.description: Detects promises that lack .catch() handlers or async functions without try/catch blocks, which can lead to unhandled promise rejections.

patterns.title: nopaging => true
patterns.description: Detects WP_Query calls with 'nopaging' => true, which disables pagination and retrieves all matching posts, potentially causing memory exhaustion.

patterns.title: Randomized ordering (ORDER BY RAND)
patterns.description: Detects queries using ORDER BY RAND() or 'orderby' => 'rand', which causes full table scans and is extremely slow on large datasets.

patterns.title: Dynamic PHP include/require with variables
patterns.description: Detects include/require statements where the path expression contains variables. Dynamic includes are a common source of local/remote file inclusion vulnerabilities.

patterns.title: Dangerous eval() usage in PHP
patterns.description: Detects eval() calls in PHP code, which execute arbitrary code and are almost never safe in WordPress plugins/themes.

patterns.title: Hardcoded credentials in PHP
patterns.description: Detects API keys, secrets, tokens, or passwords hardcoded into PHP source files.

patterns.title: Shell command execution functions in PHP (shell_exec/exec/system/passthru)
patterns.description: Usage of shell_exec(), exec(), system(), or passthru() in PHP code. These functions execute system commands and are almost never safe in WordPress plugins/themes.

patterns.title: Direct file write with user-controlled path
patterns.description: Detects file writes where the target path is derived directly from PHP superglobals (user-controlled input). This is a common pattern for arbitrary file write vulnerabilities.

patterns.title: Direct superglobal manipulation
patterns.description: Detects direct modification of PHP superglobals ($_GET, $_POST, $_REQUEST, $_COOKIE) which can bypass security filters and create vulnerabilities.

patterns.title: Context-aware superglobal detection with nonce verification
patterns.description: Enhanced detection that checks for nonce verification before $_POST/$_GET access. Skips findings when proper nonce + sanitization pattern is detected.

patterns.title: Timezone-sensitive patterns (current_time/date)
patterns.description: Detects timezone-sensitive functions that may cause inconsistent behavior across different server configurations. Uses current_time('timestamp') or date() without proper timezone handling.

patterns.title: Transients without expiration
patterns.description: Detects set_transient() calls that may be missing the expiration parameter. Transients without expiration can accumulate in the database and cause performance issues.

patterns.title: Unbounded numberposts
patterns.description: Detects get_posts() calls with numberposts set to -1, which retrieves all posts without limit and can cause memory exhaustion.

patterns.title: Unbounded posts_per_page
patterns.description: Detects WP_Query or get_posts() calls with posts_per_page set to -1, which retrieves all posts without limit and can cause memory exhaustion.

patterns.title: Unbounded wc_get_orders()
patterns.description: Detects wc_get_orders() calls with explicit 'limit' => -1, which hydrates full WC_Order objects indefinitely and causes OOM crashes.

patterns.title: Unbounded wc_get_products()
patterns.description: Detects wc_get_products() calls with explicit 'limit' => -1.

patterns.title: Unsanitized superglobal read ($_GET/$_POST)
patterns.description: Detects $_GET/$_POST/$_REQUEST used directly after isset/empty check on same line without sanitization

patterns.title: Unsanitized superglobal read ($_GET/$_POST/$_REQUEST)
patterns.description: Direct access to $_GET, $_POST, or $_REQUEST without sanitization functions. Unlike the isset-bypass pattern, this catches ANY unsanitized access regardless of isset/empty checks.

patterns.title: Coupon logic in WooCommerce thank-you/order-received context
patterns.description: Detects coupon-related operations (apply_coupon, remove_coupon, WC_Coupon instantiation) in WooCommerce thank-you or order-received contexts. This is a reliability anti-pattern because the order is already complete and coupon operations should not be performed post-checkout.

patterns.title: WooCommerce Smart Coupons active with potential thank-you page performance impact
patterns.description: Detects WooCommerce Smart Coupons plugin which is known to trigger expensive database queries (LOWER(post_title) lookups) on the thank-you/order-received page. This can cause 15-30 second page load times on sites with large wp_posts tables.

patterns.title: HTML-escaping in JSON response URL fields
patterns.description: Detects HTML escaping functions (esc_url, esc_attr, esc_html) used in JSON response fields with URL-like names. This can cause double-encoding issues where & becomes & breaking redirects in JavaScript.

patterns.title: Unbounded WP_Query/get_posts
patterns.description: Detects WP_Query or get_posts with posts_per_page => -1 or nopaging => true.

patterns.title: WP_User_Query Full Meta Hydration
patterns.description: Detects WP_User_Query without 'update_user_meta_cache' => false.

patterns.title: Direct database queries without $wpdb->prepare()
patterns.description: Detects $wpdb->query(), get_var(), get_row(), get_results(), or get_col() called without $wpdb->prepare() wrapper, creating SQL injection vulnerabilities.
